name.text: 001 Read the document Python's range expression, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

questiontext.text: Read the document Python's range expression, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

name.text:
002 For the next several questions, consider the following snippet of code: 
  for k in range(500): 
      print(k)

questiontext.text:
For the next several questions, consider the following snippet of code: 
  for k in range(500): 
      print(k)

name.text:
023 A student wrote the following code to compute n! (n factorial). 
product = 1 
for k in range(n, 0): 
    product = product * k
What error did the student make?

questiontext.text:
A student wrote the following code to compute n! (n factorial). 
product = 1 
for k in range(n, 0): 
    product = product * k
What error did the student make?

name.text:
024 True or false: The code snippet 
total = 0 
for k in range(m, n): 
    total = total + k 
print(total)
and 
total = 0 
for j in range(n - m): 
    total = total + j + m 
print(total)
both print the same thing.

questiontext.text:
True or false: The code snippet 
total = 0 
for k in range(m, n): 
    total = total + k 
print(total)
and 
total = 0 
for j in range(n - m): 
    total = total + j + m 
print(total)
both print the same thing.

name.text: 025 Watch the video Box and Pointer Diagrams, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

questiontext.text: Watch the video Box and Pointer Diagrams, doing the next set of questions while you do so.

name.text:
026 True or False?
A box and pointer diagram helps explain the idea that a variable is a REFERENCE to its value.

questiontext.text:
True or False?
A box and pointer diagram helps explain the idea that a variable is a REFERENCE to its value.

name.text:
027 True or False?
A box and pointer diagram helps show the CONSEQUENCES of the idea that a variable is a REFERENCE to its value.

questiontext.text:
True or False?
A box and pointer diagram helps show the CONSEQUENCES of the idea that a variable is a REFERENCE to its value.

name.text: 028 A block and pointer diagram:

questiontext.text: A block and pointer diagram:

answer.text: Shows the flow of control of a program.
Gives hints for how to ship boxes safely.
Explains why cats chase laser pointers.
Shows a snapshot of the variables and their values at a given point of a program's execution.

name.text:
029 True or False?
In Python, every piece of data is an OBJECT.

questiontext.text:
True or False?
In Python, every piece of data is an OBJECT.

Every object has a TYPE.

name.text:
035 Consider the line of code: 
 c2 = rg.Circle(rg.Point(100, 300), 45)
Are the following equivalent?
c2 REFERS to the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.
c2 POINTS to the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.
c2 is the NAME OF the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.

questiontext.text:
Consider the line of code: 
 c2 = rg.Circle(rg.Point(100, 300), 45)
Are the following equivalent?
c2 REFERS to the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.
c2 POINTS to the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.
c2 is the NAME OF the rg.Circle whose center is at (100, 300) and whose radius is 45.

name.text: 039 Which of the following are CONTAINER objects?

name.text:
040 Consider the Python statement: 
 temperature = 98.6
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram of that statement?

questiontext.text:
Consider the Python statement: 
 temperature = 98.6
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram of that statement?

answer.text: The FIRST diagram (on the top) is correct.
The SECOND diagram (on the bottom) is correct.

name.text:
041 Consider the Python statement: 
 center = rg.Point(50, 30)
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram of that statement?

questiontext.text:
Consider the Python statement: 
 center = rg.Point(50, 30)
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram of that statement?

answer.text: The FIRST diagram (on the top) is correct.
The SECOND diagram (in the middle) is correct.
The THIRD diagram (on the bottom) is correct.

name.text:
042 Consider the code snippet: 
 x = 50 
 y = 30 
 center = rg.Point(x, y)
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram for that snippet?

questiontext.text:
Consider the code snippet: 
 x = 50 
 y = 30 
 center = rg.Point(x, y)
Which of the following is a correct box-and-pointer diagram for that snippet?

answer.text: The FIRST diagram (on the top) is correct.
The SECOND diagram (on the bottom) is correct.

name.text:
048 Consider the code snippet: 
 r = 66 
 r2 = r 
 center = rg.Point(90, 40) 
 circle = rg.Circle(center, r) 
 r = 35 
 center.x = 200 
 
 print(r) 
 print(r2) 
 print(center) 
 print(circle)
Determine IN YOUR HEAD (that is, without using a computer and without using any scratch paper) what would be printed when the above code snippet executes. In the box below, write your answer for what would be printed. (The details of how you write the center and circle are unimportant; any way is fine. Just don't use any VARIABLES in your answer. That is, use only NUMBERS and the class names rg.Circle and rg.Point.)

questiontext.text:
Consider the code snippet: 
 r = 66 
 r2 = r 
 center = rg.Point(90, 40) 
 circle = rg.Circle(center, r) 
 r = 35 
 center.x = 200 
 
 print(r) 
 print(r2) 
 print(center) 
 print(circle)
Determine IN YOUR HEAD (that is, without using a computer and without using any scratch paper) what would be printed when the above code snippet executes. In the box below, write your answer for what would be printed. (The details of how you write the center and circle are unimportant; any way is fine. Just don't use any VARIABLES in your answer. That is, use only NUMBERS and the class names rg.Circle and rg.Point.)
